description: Borrowed from Middle French metropole (“town with bishop's seat”), from Latin mētropolis. Doublet of metropolis.

entries.meaning: A metropolis; the main city of a country or area. [from 15th c.]
The parent-state of a colony. [from 19th c.]
examples: Though the metropole remained confident in its Westminster ways, its newly independent colonies imposed constitutional constraints on the powers of parliament.
